stages.description: Tiny pale seeds, barely a millimeter long, that need light to germinate — press into the surface, never bury.
Radicle pushes down while cotyledons lift free of the seed coat, pale and rounded like miniature paddles.
First true leaves emerge — small, rounded, and impossibly tender, already hinting at the buttery texture to come.
Leaves unfurl in overlapping rosette layers, outer ones spreading wide while inner leaves cup inward to form a loose, silky head.
A central stalk shoots up through the head — the dreaded bolt. Small yellow composite flowers open like tiny dandelions. Leaves turn bitter.
Flowers give way to tufted seed heads. Each seed carries a tiny white pappus for wind dispersal, like a dandelion in miniature.
The stalk dries brown and brittle. Remaining leaves wither. Seeds scatter on the wind.

companions.lore: Carrots and lettuce are classic garden partners — the deep-rooted carrots break up soil below while shallow-rooted lettuce marks the row for slow-germinating carrot seedlings.
Pea root nodules fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil, feeding this hungry leafy green. The pea vines also cast dappled shade that delays bolting.
Lettuce and strawberries share similar water needs and root depths. The lettuce acts as living mulch, keeping strawberry roots cool and moist.

antagonists.lore: Fennel's root exudates contain anethole and other compounds that suppress lettuce germination and stunt growth. A notorious garden bully.

stages.description: Angular yellow patches appear between leaf veins. Faint gray fuzz visible on undersides in morning dew.
Yellow patches turn brown and papery. Leaves curl downward. Fuzzy gray sporulation spreads across leaf undersides.
Outer leaves collapse into a slimy mat. Inner head remains firm but unmarketable. The oomycete has overwhelmed the plant.
Inner leaf margins turn brown and papery. Calcium can't reach fast-growing heart leaves — the plant is growing faster than it can hydrate.
Brown edges expand inward. Affected leaves become papery and brittle. Secondary bacterial rot may set in on damaged tissue.
Rust-brown spots appear where lower leaves touch wet soil. The soilborne fungus Rhizoctonia attacks from below.
Brown rot creeps up the stem. Lower leaves become slimy and collapse. A faint web of fungal threads visible at the soil line.
The entire head topples as the base rots through. The plant separates from its roots when lifted.

lore.description: Soft, cupped leaves fold into a loose head with a texture like silk — the gentlest of the lettuces, and the fastest path from seed to salad.
lore.origin: Mediterranean basin; cultivated since ancient Egypt, where lettuce was sacred to the fertility god Min
lore.fun_fact: The name 'lettuce' comes from Latin lactuca, meaning milk — snap a stem and you'll see the white latex that ancient Romans believed was a mild sedative.
